definitions.Definition: Distance from the nucleus to the outer most electron
Tendency of an atom to attract a shared pair of electrons towards itself
Amount of energy it takes to remove an electron from an atom
Amount of energy released when an atom gains an electron
Formed between metal & non-metal (or polyatomic ion)
Formed between 2 non-metals. Electrons are shared between the atoms
Electrons are not shared equally between the atoms; some electrons are closer to one atom than the other
Electrons are shared equally between both atoms
Formed between metal atoms. Electrons do not belong to any particular atom but are rather shared between all atoms in a “sea” like structure. Because of this, the ionization energy is very low
Formed between metal & non-metal (or polyatomic ion)
Formed between 2 non-metals. Electrons are shared between the atoms
If the compound has a polar bond and is also asymmetrical, the compound will have a slight charge
If the compound has a polar bond and is also symmetrical, or if the compound has a non-polar bond, the compound will have no charge
Weakest intermolecular force that exists within all molecules. Occurs when electrons from both atoms are more towards one end of the molecule, giving that side a slight charge.
Exists within asymmetrical polar molecules. One side of the molecule has a slight positive charge, the other has a slight negative charge
Strongest intermolecular force that exists only between Hydrogen atoms bonded to Nitrogen, Oxygen and/or Fluorine
An atom having 8 electrons in its outer most shell
Atoms after the 3d energy level can have a total of more than 8 valence electrons
A + B → AB
AB → A + B
AB + C → AC + B
AB + CD → AD + CB (No reaction occurs if all products are aqueous)
Metal + O&#8322 → Metal Oxide
Acid + Base → Water + Salt
How close a measurement is to the true value
Consistency between the values
Every digit you’re sure about + first digit you’re not sure about
Unit of measurement, approximately 6.02 x 10&sup2³
Mass of 1 mol of particles (usually calculated to 2 decimal places) - Equal to atomic mass
Final answer can only have as many decimal places as the least precise number given in the problem
Final answer can only have as many significant digits as the number with the least significant digits given in the problem
Lowest whole-number ratio of a molecular formula
How the molecule actually exists in nature
Mass of the element in compound / total mass of the compound
Hydrocarbon reacts with excess oxygen to determine the elemental composition of the compound
Hydrate is heated until there is no more water, then the difference in mass can be used to determine the moles of water
Relationship between the reactants and products in a chemical equation
The substance that is totally consumed when the chemical reaction is complete. The amount of product formed is limited by this reagent, since the reaction cannot continue without it
Homogeneous mixture of two or more substances
Substance that dissolves in solvent to become a solution (Usually substance that is in lesser quantity)
Becomes a solution by dissolving a solute. Usually a liquid (Usually substance that is in higher quantity)
A mixture that contains one visible part
A mixture that contains two or more visible parts
Ratio of the quantity of solute to the quantity of solution or solvent
Solution with a relatively large quantity of solute dissolved per unit volume of solution
Solution with a relatively small quantity of solute dissolved per unit volume of solution
Solution of two or more metals
Solution in which water is the solvent
Scale used to specify how acidic or basic a water-based solution is. Higher = more acidic
Substance that is capable of donating a hydrogen ion
Substance that is capable of accepting a hydrogen ion
Process in which ions are surrounded by water molecules
Separation of individual ions from an ionic compound as it dissolves in water
Solution that contains the maximum quantity of solute at a given temperature and pressure
Solution in which more solute can dissolve at a given temperature and pressure
Solution that contains more than the maximum quantity of solute that it should at a given temperature and pressure
Moles of solute/Liters of solution
Ratio of volume of solute to volume of solution
Process of reducing the concentration of a solution; usually done by adding more solvent
Ions that are not involved in a chemical reaction
Chemical equation that includes only the entities that react during the reaction
Chemical reaction in which a compound breaks apart into two or more components
Small specified amount of solution
Substance that absorbs water in variable amounts
Quantitative chemical analysis to determine the concentration of an identified analyte
Point right pass the equivalence point; Where the indicator changes color
Perfect stoichiometric amounts where the acid and base have neutralized each other
Substance that changes color depending on the pH of the substance it reacts with
Precipitation reaction used to quantify a substance based on mass
Adding a known volume of solution with known concentration to a known volume of unknown concentration (analyte)
An acid is defined as any substance that dissociates in water to produce H+ ions, and a base is any substance that dissociates in water to produce OH- ions.
An acid is a substance that donates a proton (H+), and a base is a substance that accepts a proton (H+).
A chemical compound formed by the reception of a proton (H+) by a base
Arrangement of electrons within an atom
Model used to predict the geometry of individual molecules from the number of electron pairs surrounding their central atoms
Volume is directly proportional to temperature
Pressure is inversely proportional to volume
Pressure is directly proportional to temperature
The amount (mole) of gas is directly proportional to the volume; Equal volumes of all ideal gases at the same temperature and pressure contain the same number of molecules.
The total pressure of a mixture of gases is the sum of the pressures of each of the individual gases
25 &#176C and 100 kPa
Forces that exist between molecules
Forces that hold atoms together in a molecule
An atom is a small dense nucleus surrounded by orbiting electrons
Space around an atom where the electrons are most likely to be
Chemical property that measures the ability of substance (solute) to dissolve in a solvent
Scale used to specify how acidic or basic a water-based solution is. Higher = more basic
Refers to the tendency of an acid to dissociate into ions in a aqueous solution
Refers to the tendency of a base to dissociate into ions in a aqueous solution
